title: FirstFT: Chinese stocks fall over Evergrande fears
text:
Chinese stock markets fell on their first day of trading this week after a public holiday as concerns grew over a possible default by property developer Evergrande on an international bond repayment.

But the losses were not as heavy as feared after the real estate company, which has total liabilities of more than $300bn, said a payment due on Thursday for an onshore renminbi-denominated bond had “already been resolved through off-exchange negotiations”.

Evergrande is due to pay Rmb232m ($35.8m) in interest on the onshore bond maturing in 2025. But the company did not comment on exactly when or how much of that amount it would pay, or whether it would meet an $83.5m payment also due on Thursday for an offshore, dollar-denominated note that matures next year. That bond has traded at about 26 cents on the dollar this week, reflecting expectations of imminent default.

Concern that the company will default on the offshore bond sparked broader tumult in global markets this week, with Wall Street on Monday suffering its worst trading day since May.

Shares rose elsewhere in Asia and in Europe today on hopes that Evergrande might reach a similar arrangement with its international bondholders. Futures for the S&P 500 swung from a loss to a gain following the onshore bond deal's announcement.

Meanwhile, funds managed by BlackRock and HSBC added to their holdings of Evergrande bonds months before the liquidity crisis at the Chinese property developer pushed it to the brink of default, the FT reports.

Five more stories in the news

1. UK hopes to join US-Mexico-Canada trade pact British officials said yesterday that the UK was considering applying to join USMCA, the trade pact signed by Donald Trump, as hopes fade for a bilateral agreement with Washington. Meanwhile, Joe Biden warned Boris Johnson not to allow a dispute over the post-Brexit settlement to destabilise the Northern Ireland peace process at a White House meeting between the two leaders.

2. SoftBank backs Steven Mnuchin's private equity fund Japan's SoftBank has followed Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund and Abu Dhabi's Mubadala in backing a new $2.5bn private equity fund set up by the former US Treasury secretary — just eight months after he left office.

3. CO2 crisis set to spread to Europe The UK carbon dioxide shortage threatening industries from steel to food is spilling over into Europe, Nippon Gases, one of the world's largest distributors of the gas, has warned. It follows comments from the Paris-based IEA yesterday that Russia should send more gas to Europe to help alleviate the energy crisis.

4. OECD warns of rising inflation risks Inflation will continue to rise over the next two years, according to revised projections by the OECD, which expects price increases to be significantly higher in 2021 and in 2022 than it previously forecast for most G20 countries.

5. DraftKings makes bid to acquire UK rival The US fantasy sports and sports betting company has made a roughly £16.6bn offer for the UK gambling company Entain, the second time this year a rival has sought to acquire the business.

Coronavirus digest

  • The Democratic-controlled House of Representatives has passed a bill to avert a government shutdown on October 1 and extend the US debt limit until December next year. The proposed legislation, however, is highly unlikely to be approved by the Senate, risking a full-blown fiscal crisis.

  • South-east Asian countries that failed to administer Covid-19 vaccines fast enough are suffering outbreaks of the disease that are causing a growing regional economic divergence, the Asian Development Bank has warned.

  • A booster of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine increases protection against symptomatic Covid-19 to 94 per cent, the company said yesterday.

  • The end of extra federal unemployment benefits for millions of Americans this month is unlikely to provide a significant boost to the US labour market, according to an analysis by the Financial Times.

Thanks to those readers who voted in our latest poll. Four-fifths of you agreed with Joe Biden's decision to relax the rules for overseas travellers to the US from early November.

The day ahead

Federal Reserve concludes monetary policy meeting The Fed will offer forecasts on when interest rates will begin to rise at the conclusion of its two-day Federal Open Market Committee meeting today. Policymakers are expected to offer clues to the stimulus taper timeline.

Joe Biden hosts Covid-19 summit The US president will urge world leaders to step up commitments to share vaccines, address worldwide oxygen shortages and other pandemic issues at the virtual gathering, timed to coincide with the annual UN General Assembly meeting this week. Separately, the Food and Drug Administration is expected to decide as soon as today on a recommendation for Covid-19 boosters made by Pfizer.

Earnings General Mills is expected to post a dip in first-quarter revenue as the reopening of restaurants has slowed demand for packaged foods. The Cheerios cereal maker may also make comments on inflation.

EU energy ministers meet Officials will meet today to discuss national responses to the surge in wholesale gas prices, amid concern that they will jeopardise Europe's post-pandemic economic recovery and undermine Brussels' plans for ambitious but costly green reforms.

What else we're reading and listening to

Wall Street embraces the ‘forever CEO' In the past decade, large US banks' chiefs have rarely stepped down unless forced to do so: Jamie Dimon, Brian Moynihan and James Gorman are among those who have spurned shorter tenures. But this trend can serve as a roadblock in the push towards greater diversity in corporate America.

“When things are going well you don't want to leave but when things are going poorly you feel you can't leave” — Lloyd Blankfein, former Goldman Sachs chief executive

Inequality is behind central bank dilemma There is a worry that persistent price shocks get baked into expectations, which will only be reversed by a period of significantly higher short-term rates. That would cause stagflation, creating devastating problems for weaker borrowers, notably in heavily indebted emerging economies, writes Martin Wolf.

  • Go deeper: My colleague Robert Armstrong yesterday interviewed former treasury secretary Larry Summers and well-known academic Nouriel Roubini, and they are both very concerned about inflation.

Decarbonising takes thousands of tiny steps Stunts and pious pledges won't save the planet, writes Brooke Masters. Manufacturers and retailers must rethink their entire design, manufacturing and sales processes. Those that have are finding that change is either expensive or unglamorous — but necessary to cut carbon emissions.

Coping with the chaos that is hybrid working On returning to work after the holidays I have discovered some flaws in my new hybrid working life, writes Emma Jacobs. First, I kept leaving my phone charger at home. Then I absent-mindedly scheduled meetings that meant coming into the office every day. This is part of a Future of the Workplace special report.

FT readers' biggest financial mistakes Following the launch of our Financial Literacy and Inclusion Campaign, FT journalists confessed their worst financial blunders. Now it's your turn. From gambling to buying a boat, here are some of the lessons you learnt from those experiences.

How should we teach young people about personal finance? Tune in to our live Q&A with Claer Barrett and Aimée Allam, director of FT Flic, here as they answer your questions today at midday UK time.

Film

Love affairs, like many things, are subject to the laws of time and change. So film critic Nigel Andrews is blown away by the fact that he is still captivated by Spirited Away, the Japanese animation film, on which he bestowed six stars out of five.
